In communities where the weight of survival is a daily struggle, the concept of "childhood" as a period of leisure and learning is a luxury afforded only to the privileged. In such places, every member of the family must contribute to the survival of the whole. The children, with their nimble hands, tireless energy, and low cost to employers, become a vital resource. They are not a burden—they are a blessing in the form of a worker.

Think of it this way: when a family is starving, and the only way to put food on the table is for the children to work, then allowing them to work is not exploitation. It is love. It is sacrifice. It is a father’s duty to see his children fed, even if it means sending them into the fields, the factories, or the mines. A child who works is a child who eats. A child who learns the value of hard labor is a child who understands the dignity of earning one’s place in the world.

And what of education? In places where schools are scarce, where teachers are absent, and where books are a distant dream, what good is a classroom? The real education a child receives is in the hands of a carpenter, the back of a farmer, or the discipline of a factory line. These are the schools of survival, the academies of resilience. They teach a child not only how to work, but how to endure. And in the end, that is what life demands.

Let us not romanticize poverty, but neither should we ignore the reality of it. To impose the moral standards of the wealthy upon the poor is to deny them their agency, their dignity, and their right to choose what is best for their own families. Child labor is not a violation—it is a choice. A necessary one.

And remember: every generation must rise through its own struggles. The children who work today will build a stronger future for their families tomorrow.
